Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise how language empowers relationships and roles
Elaboration: Identifying the various communities to which students belong and how language reinforces membership of these communities; for example, the intimate language of family members, the jargon of teenage groups, the technicality of some online communities, the language specific to recreational groups and the interaction patterns of the classroom
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •exploring if this use of language exists in the students’ home anguage

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise how language empowers relationships and roles
Elaboration: Exploring language used by first nations australian authors to reinforce relationships to country/place and with others; for example, “hello” in turrabul language is “galang nguruindhau”

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how evaluation can be expressed directly and indirectly using devices such as allusion, evocative vocabulary and metaphor
Elaboration: Comparing texts that use evaluative language in different ways; for example, print advertisements, editorials, talkback radio, podcasts and poetry, and identifying wording that appraises indirectly through evocative language, similes and metaphors that direct readers’ views in particular ways
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •explanations of the cultural and historical knowledge required to identify and interpret allusion .g. ‘If you are not home by midnight, your car might turn into a pumpkin.’ (a reference to the fairytale, Cinderella), ‘Herculean effort’ (a reference to the strength of Hercules from classical mythology) •creating word banks and vocabulary clines showing graduation of emotional strength of words

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Examine how authors adapt and subvert text structures and language features by experimenting with spoken, written, visual and multimodal elements, and their combination
Elaboration: Comparing the use of linear and non-linear narratives in a range of short stories, and determining the purpose and effect of the different structures
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •creating a timeline to show important events in a non-linear short story as they would have happened in chronological order, and another timeline to show these events as they actually appear in the short story

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Examine how authors adapt and subvert text structures and language features by experimenting with spoken, written, visual and multimodal elements, and their combination
Elaboration: Comparing the opening paragraphs of different public texts such as feature articles, and determining the purpose and effect of the different structures and language features

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Investigate a range of cohesive devices that condense information in texts, including nominalisation, and devices that link, expand and develop ideas, including text connectives
Elaboration: Sequencing and developing an argument using language structures that suggest conclusions (“therefore”, “moreover” and “so”) or give reasons (“since”, “because”) or suggest conditionals (“if … then”)
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •teacher modelled and guided opportunities to practice condensing information in sentences using nominalisation, for example ‘The students were thinking about all the homework they had to do and this made them worried.’ - ‘The thought of all the homework they had to do made them worried.’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Identify how authors vary sentence structures creatively for effects, such as intentionally using a dependent clause on its own or a sentence fragment
Elaboration: Identifying the effects of using an interrupting clause inside another clause; for example, “his friend, who had left home the previous year, suddenly returned.”, intentionally using a dependent clause on its own; for example, “if you see what i mean.” or using a sentence fragment; for example, “breathtaking!”
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •guided practice to vary sentence structure and explain the effects

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how abstract nouns and nominalisation can be used to summarise ideas in text
Elaboration: Exploring sections of academic and technical texts, and analysing the use of abstract nouns; for example, “the previous argument”, “the prologue”, to summarise and distil information, structure the argument and summarise preceding explanations
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •development of a word bank and guided practice to identify abstract nouns and nominalisation used to summarise and distil information in texts

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Analyse how symbols in still and moving images augment meaning
Elaboration: Investigating the use of symbols; for example, specific seasons, weather and colours in images, films and picture books, and evaluating their contribution to viewers’ understanding, recognising that visual and verbal symbols have different meanings for different groups and cultures
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •inclusion of still and moving images that reflect the cultural and linguistic diversity of students in the class to broaden discussion of symbols

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Analyse how symbols in still and moving images augment meaning
Elaboration: Understanding the use of symbols by first nations australians, where a symbol may have many meanings or have different meanings across first nations australian groups; for example, artwork enables first nations australians from a particular country/place to identify symbols and interpret the artwork

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Analyse how vocabulary choices contribute to style, mood and tone
Elaboration: Identifying the words used to create nuanced meaning; for example, identifying the words that create a sarcastic tone in a text
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •building a bank of words associated with style, mood and tone created in a short story or chapter of a novel

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Analyse how vocabulary choices contribute to style, mood and tone
Elaboration: Identifying the words used to create nuanced meaning; for example, identifying the words that create a sarcastic tone in a text
EALDElaboration: •listening to spoken texts and participating in teacher-supported discussions about the word choices that contribute to a particular tone, e.g. a political speech

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Analyse how vocabulary choices contribute to style, mood and tone
Elaboration: Identifying how the vocabulary used in a text contributes to its stylistic effectiveness

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand punctuation conventions for referencing and citing others for formal and informal purposes
Elaboration: Understanding who to and how to cite in essays, reviews and academic assignments, and when it is appropriate to use direct quotations or to report sources more generally
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •clear explanation and examples of punctuation conventions

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse the representations of people and places in literary texts, drawn from historical, social and cultural contexts, by first nations australian, and wide-ranging australian and world authors
Elaboration: Exploring and comparing representations of values of characters; for example, exploring the values associated with authority, community and family in literature drawn from different cultures and times
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •encouragement to share their knowledge of literary texts they have read in their home language and inclusion of literary texts reflecting cultural diversity

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse the representations of people and places in literary texts, drawn from historical, social and cultural contexts, by first nations australian, and wide-ranging australian and world authors
Elaboration: Exploring how texts by first nations australian authors reflect unique ways of being, knowing, thinking and doing

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse the representations of people and places in literary texts, drawn from historical, social and cultural contexts, by first nations australian, and wide-ranging australian and world authors
Elaboration: Exploring the way wide-ranging australian novels, poems and films represent water and characters’ relationships with water

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Present a personal response to a literary text comparing initial impressions and subsequent analysis of the whole text
Elaboration: Interrogating and making judgements about a text, comparing others’ ideas against the student’s own and reaching an independent decision or consensus about the interpretations and ideas expressed
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •the opportunity to model, brainstorm vocabulary and refine their personal response to a text in a smaller group before sharing ideas with a larger group

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Analyse how features of literary texts influence readers’ preference for texts
Elaboration: Reflecting on and discussing responses to literature including characterisation, setting details, plot events, themes and literary devices used to achieve particular effects, and collaboratively formulating a list of factors that distinguish value
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •identifying texts that they enjoy, including those from their home language, and recording the features of these texts that add to that enjoyment on a graphic organiser

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse texts and evaluate the aesthetic qualities and appeal of an author’s literary style
Elaboration: Comparing texts created by the same author to determine literary style, assessing their appeal and presenting comparisons to others
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •opportunities to analyse and evaluate literary texts from their home language

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse the effect of text structures, language features and literary devices such as extended metaphor, metonymy, allegory, symbolism and intertextual references
Elaboration: Examining how different authors make use of devices such as imagery, and explaining the effect of these choices on audiences
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •teacher-supported discussions of intertextual references with explanations of a reference in its original form and the link to the newer text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse the effect of text structures, language features and literary devices such as extended metaphor, metonymy, allegory, symbolism and intertextual references
Elaboration: Examining how different authors make use of devices such as imagery, and explaining the effect of these choices on audiences
EALDElaboration: •clear explanations of the cultural and historical knowledge required to identify and interpret symbolism

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse the effect of text structures, language features and literary devices such as extended metaphor, metonymy, allegory, symbolism and intertextual references
Elaboration: Identifying examples of literary devices in a range of poems and considering how they contribute to meaning and influence the emotional responses of the audience

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit literary texts, that may be a hybrid, that experiment with text structures, language features and literary devices for purposes and audiences
Elaboration: Taking an existing short story, poem, play or speech in print form and creating a short film
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •revising text structure frameworks to understand specific types of texts and then engaging in teacher– supported joint construction of short hybrid texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit literary texts, that may be a hybrid, that experiment with text structures, language features and literary devices for purposes and audiences
Elaboration: Adapting traditional and contemporary literature through textual intervention, prequel or sequel

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit literary texts, that may be a hybrid, that experiment with text structures, language features and literary devices for purposes and audiences
Elaboration: Editing by checking for run-on sentences, ensuring that detail or repetition is used for effect, and ensuring paragraphs are linked in ways that develop the narrative

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse how representations of people, places, events and concepts reflect contexts
Elaboration: Examining the representation of public figures in media and recognising how these vary in different contexts
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •inclusion of texts that reflect their cultural heritage and opportunities to analyse representations of people, places, events and concepts in these texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse how representations of people, places, events and concepts reflect contexts
Elaboration: Identifying and analysing how news is conveyed in texts; for example, analysing representations of an event at a particular time reported in the media

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse how representations of people, places, events and concepts reflect contexts
Elaboration: Comparing texts from different time periods and analysing the language features used to represent individuals or groups

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Listen to spoken texts that have different purposes and audiences, analysing how language features position listeners to respond in particular ways, and use interacting skills to present and discuss opinions regarding these texts
Elaboration: Discussing how stereotypes are created through language and how they position listeners to respond
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •previewing key language and concepts and listening to spoken texts more than once

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Listen to spoken texts that have different purposes and audiences, analysing how language features position listeners to respond in particular ways, and use interacting skills to present and discuss opinions regarding these texts
Elaboration: Discussing how stereotypes are created through language and how they position listeners to respond
EALDElaboration: •having access to the written script of a spoken text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Listen to spoken texts that have different purposes and audiences, analysing how language features position listeners to respond in particular ways, and use interacting skills to present and discuss opinions regarding these texts
Elaboration: Using effective strategies for dialogue and discussion in a range of formal and informal contexts, including speaking clearly and coherently and for an appropriate length of time, presenting an opinion and listening to the opinions of others

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse and evaluate how language features are used to represent a perspective of an issue, event, situation, individual or group
Elaboration: Analysing the use of language in the coverage of a contentious issue in a range of news and social media
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •alternative methods of eliciting this information, such as graphic organisers, a teacher interview, or creation of a multimedia response

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse and evaluate how language features are used to represent a perspective of an issue, event, situation, individual or group
Elaboration: Analysing the use of language in the coverage of a contentious issue in a range of news and social media
EALDElaboration: •creating word clines of descriptive language encountered in texts to show how language choice can represent a range of perspectives

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse and evaluate how language features are used to represent a perspective of an issue, event, situation, individual or group
Elaboration: Explaining how authors use language features to represent ideas and convey opinions

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse and evaluate how language features are used to represent a perspective of an issue, event, situation, individual or group
Elaboration: Comparing a range of advocacy, campaign or inspirational speeches from films or media and identifying language features that influence the listener

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse the organisation of ideas in paragraphs and extended texts, and evaluate its impact on meaning
Elaboration: Evaluating techniques used in texts to organise ideas and evoke emotional responses, such as comparison, contrast, exaggeration, juxtaposition, the changing of chronological order, and the expansion and compression of time
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •representing text organisation using graphic organisers to support the evaluation.

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse the organisation of ideas in paragraphs and extended texts, and evaluate its impact on meaning
Elaboration: Evaluating techniques used in texts to organise ideas and evoke emotional responses, such as comparison, contrast, exaggeration, juxtaposition, the changing of chronological order, and the expansion and compression of time
EALDElaboration: •development of a word bank to support their use of metalanguage to describe text features

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse the organisation of ideas in paragraphs and extended texts, and evaluate its impact on meaning
Elaboration: Explaining whether the author conveys meaning effectively, through the sequence of information and evidence

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring, questioning and inferring to compare and contrast ideas and opinions in and between texts
Elaboration: Comparing and contrasting visual representations of ideas, issues or events in online news reporting
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •use of visuals such as graphic organisers or retrieval charts to help identify and organize ideas

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring, questioning and inferring to compare and contrast ideas and opinions in and between texts
Elaboration: Comparing the representation of an event in print and digital sources, summarising their qualities, identifying opinions and analysing evidence

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring, questioning and inferring to compare and contrast ideas and opinions in and between texts
Elaboration: Summarising articles representing a current event comparing and contrasting ideas and opinions in and between texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, edit and publish written and multimodal texts, organising, expanding and developing ideas, and selecting text structures, language features, literary devices and multimodal features for purposes and audiences in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive, analytical and/or critical
Elaboration: Developing an argument that has a series of sequenced and linked paragraphs, beginning with a contention, followed by a series of supported points that develop a line of argument, and a conclusion that summarises the main line of argument
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •teacher–supported deconstruction of model texts, modelling of planning for writing and joint construction of sample paragraphs or texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, edit and publish written and multimodal texts, organising, expanding and developing ideas, and selecting text structures, language features, literary devices and multimodal features for purposes and audiences in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive, analytical and/or critical
Elaboration: Creating informative texts that explain and analyse complex phenomena using well-chosen facts and precise language

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, edit and publish written and multimodal texts, organising, expanding and developing ideas, and selecting text structures, language features, literary devices and multimodal features for purposes and audiences in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive, analytical and/or critical
Elaboration: Reviewing and editing their own and others’ texts, which may involve using online applications, for accuracy of grammar, spelling and punctuation, and to achieve particular purposes and address specific audiences by improving clarity and control of content through organising, developing, extending and linking ideas

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, edit and publish written and multimodal texts, organising, expanding and developing ideas, and selecting text structures, language features, literary devices and multimodal features for purposes and audiences in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive, analytical and/or critical
Elaboration: Discussing choices of literary devices used in a literary text with a peer, and evaluating the potential effect of each choice on an audience

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, rehearse and deliver spoken and multimodal presentations for purposes and audiences, using language features, literary devices and features of voice such as volume, tone, pitch and pace, and organising, expanding and developing ideas in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive, analytical and/or critical
Elaboration: Using graphics and text animations to accompany spoken text; for example, presenting a news item suitable for a current affairs program that uses images with spoken text to influence a viewer’s response
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •teacher deconstruction of language, visual and multimodal features of model presentations.

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, rehearse and deliver spoken and multimodal presentations for purposes and audiences, using language features, literary devices and features of voice such as volume, tone, pitch and pace, and organising, expanding and developing ideas in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive, analytical and/or critical
Elaboration: Using graphics and text animations to accompany spoken text; for example, presenting a news item suitable for a current affairs program that uses images with spoken text to influence a viewer’s response
EALDElaboration: •teacher-supported and small group opportunities to rehearse spoken presentations to practice features of voice for a specific purpose and audience, e.g. a slower pace to emphasise a point in a persuasive speech

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, rehearse and deliver spoken and multimodal presentations for purposes and audiences, using language features, literary devices and features of voice such as volume, tone, pitch and pace, and organising, expanding and developing ideas in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive, analytical and/or critical
Elaboration: Selecting features of voice such as tone, volume, pitch and pace for their specific effects to create tone or to persuade an audience

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, rehearse and deliver spoken and multimodal presentations for purposes and audiences, using language features, literary devices and features of voice such as volume, tone, pitch and pace, and organising, expanding and developing ideas in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive, analytical and/or critical
Elaboration: Choosing text structures and adapting literary devices such as similes, metaphors and personification to meet the perceived needs of an audience when debating a topic, creating a voiceover for a media presentation or presenting a seminar

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, rehearse and deliver spoken and multimodal presentations for purposes and audiences, using language features, literary devices and features of voice such as volume, tone, pitch and pace, and organising, expanding and developing ideas in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive, analytical and/or critical
Elaboration: Collaborating with peers to develop imaginative recreations of part of a text or to represent a key idea in a text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how spelling is used in texts for particular effects; for example, characterisation, humour and to represent accents and distinctive speech
Elaboration: Exploring the spelling of neologisms and their effect in media texts such as online posts; for example, “selfie” and “paralympics”
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •explanation of examples of distinctive speech achieved by an author’s spelling of particular words in a piece of dialogue

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how spelling is used in texts for particular effects; for example, characterisation, humour and to represent accents and distinctive speech
Elaboration: Analysing how spelling is used to represent the distinctive speech of a character by noting where authors have dropped letters from words to emulate the sound of spoken words
